oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Governor Prentice Cooper's 1942 inauguration, representing his third consecutive term. Flowers appear in the foreground, and Govenor Prentice Cooper and his numerous military officials are gathered in his office behind; the desk. Jacob McGavock Dickinson is located fourth from the right in this image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Prentice Cooper served three consective terms as Tennessee's fourty-fourth governor (1939-1945). Notably, he led a tireless drive to mobilize the state for World War II. This effort would come to include organizing the State Defense Council, forming the Tennessee State Guard, overseeing the state's vast war industries, and constructing fifteen armories and numerous large military bases. He was the Commander-in-Chief of the Tennessee State Guard, and he would remain actively involved in their operations.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The parade marshal for the Army Day Parade was Col. H. H. Corson of the Tennessee State Guard. He and his motorcycle escort led the army units with nine hundred infantrymen, bands, and artillery attachments. Various other military organizations participated in the event. The parade marched in front of Gov. Prentice Cooper and what newspapers called the "biggest Nashville crowd in years." Planes from the Vultee plant and Civil Air Patrol flew over downtown Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee State Guard was formed in 1941 to serve as the state's voluntee force after the Tennessee National Guard had been federalized for service in World War II. With the governor functioning as Commander-in-Chief, the State Guard's duties involved maintaining order, acting as an anti-sabotage unit, assisting during domestic and natural emergencies, cooperating with local and federal military authorities, and performing assigned armed forces duty in the state.

The Brigadier General is wearing his military uniform with the Tennessee State Guard insignia shoulder patch prominently displayed. The design for the patch was inspired by the Tennessee state flag. The three-inch in diameter patch had white stars in a dark blue center circle and a red outer ring with the white lettering of "Tennessee State Guard."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee State Guard was formed in 1941 to serve as the state's volunteer military force after the Tennessee National Guard had been federalized for service in World War II. Franklin's renowned Arabian horse breeder, Jacob McGavock Dickinson, had a noted military career in World War I. Commander-in-Chief Govenor Prentice Cooper called upon Dickinson to first command the Second Regiment (Middle Tennessee) as a colonel, then the Second Brigade as one of the three brigadier generals in the state

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of a monthly meeting held on May 17, 1942 of the Second Tennessee Infantry. This meeting, held at the Noel Hotel, was the last prior to activation of the Tennessee State Guard brigades. At the meeting, Govenor Prentice Cooper announced forty promotions in the Tennessee Guard expansion program. Included in the promotion was J.M. Dickinson, promoted to brigadier general of the Second Brigade. At the time of activation and throughout 1942, the Second Brigade was the largest State Guard brigade.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In October of 1942, it was arranged that approximately 100 of the State Guard's 650 officers would be sent to Fort Oglethorpe, Georgia for training. The officers left on October 17th and returned at the end of the month. The Tennessee State Guard was the first unit of its kind to be extended the facilities of the United States Army and to receive training under Army officers. While the training took place, Governor Prentice Cooper made an inspection tour. With this exercise, Tennessee became the first state to pay state guardsmen for their services.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William Prentice Cooper (1895-1969), a Democrat from Bedford County, served as governor from 1939 to 1945. Before becoming governor, he was elected for one term in the state House of Representatives (1923) and was then elected district attorney. After his term as governor, he served as ambassador to Peru and as a member of the 1953 Constitutional Convention.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Members of the 7th Regiment of the Tennessee State Guard participated in the first large-scale maneuvers of the organization held in Cookeville. Most of the maneuvers took place on the farm of Captain Joe Scott. The maneuvers included simulated paratroop landings. Several planes of the Civilian Air Patrol also participated in the maneuvers. The maneuvers were declared a success and proved that the State Guard could handle a major defense problem.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Part of Governor Prentice Cooper's tireless drive to mobilize the state for World War II involved developing and overseeing the state's war industries. The intial airplane factory located along Briley Parkway and adjacent to Berry Field was built in the late 1930s. Voltee Aircraft purchased the facility in 1940 and became the first defense plant in the area, employing a large number of women during the war.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jacob McGavock Dickinson's Traveler's Rest Arabian Stud Farm (River Grange Farm) on Del Rio Pike in Franklin played host to two hundred members of the 2nd Infantry Brigade for a two-day field exercise May 19-20, 1945. This event also included the Officers' School pictured. The three regiments participating in the field exercise were commanded by Col. John M. Abernathy, Pulaski; Col. Walter K. Crawford, Cookeville; and Col. Victor H. Wilson, Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cartoons (Commentary); Political cartoons; Propaganda; Publicity; Public opinion; Slogans; Press; Insignia; Bayonets
Tennessee. Militia; Tennessee - History, Military; World War, 1939-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Political cartoon featureing a uniformed Tennessee State Guard member crouched with his bayonet at the ready. The backdrop is the emblem for the State Guard. A list appears at the top right of the types of drills and skills that are involved. The bottom statements address criticism and encourage enlistment.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee State Guard, 1941-1947
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cartoons and promotions like this appeared in newspapers across the state beginning in the summer of 1943. Their placement heralded an enlistment drive; the Tennessee State Guard forces continued to lose their younger trained members to the Regular Army. A frequently mentioned membership goal was 10,000; the Guard averaged 7,800 during the major periods of military hostility, but experienced a constant drain. The cartoons and promotions were also used an an opportunity to address common criticisms.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This patriotic newspaper cartoon/promotion for the Guard appearing in the Williamson County News features in the upper right-hand corner an image of a shadowy,helmeted soldier with his weapon raised. The accompanying text emphasizes the wide range of ages that are welcome, the enlistment period, the drill expectations, and the benefit that the State Guard could be to those who later find themselves in the Regular Army.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee State Guard, 1941-1947

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cartoons and promotions like this appeared in newspapers across the state beginning in the summer of 1943. Their placement heralded an enlistment drive; the Tennessee Guard forces continued to lose their younger trained members to the Regular Army. A frequently mentioned membership goal was 10,000; the Guard averaged 7,800 during the major periods of military hostility, but experienced a constant drain. The cartoons and promotions were also used as a public relations tool to address criticisms.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Our hats off to you
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cartoons (Commentary); Political cartoons; Propaganda; Publicity; Public opinion; Slogans; Press
Tennessee. Militia; Tennessee - History, Military; World War, 1939-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Caricatures of Emperor Hirohito of Japan, Adolph Hitler of Germany, and Benito Mussolini of Italy are employed in this Tennessee State Guard promotion to remind Murfreesboro Daily News Journal readers that American apathy and "laying down on the job" are assets to our foes. Readers are encouraged to enlist and assured that they furnish nothing and that this is not a step into the Regular Army.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Seventh Regiment's large-scale maneuvers
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Militias; Military training; Military maneuvers; Boys; Teenagers; Young adults
Tennessee. Militia; Tennessee - History, Military; World War, 1939-1945
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping featureing Seventh Regiment personnel who participated in the first large-scale maneuvers for the Tennessee State Guard that were held in Cookeville August 13-15, 1943. The two photographs contrast the types and ages of men who were members of the Tennessee State Guard, from the young sixteen year-olds to the middle-aged. Also highlighted are the benefits the young men will receive from Guard membership in the Regular Army with this pre-induction training.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This clipping points up the involvement in the Tennessee State Guard, not only of those deemed too old to serve in the Regular Army, but those young men who considered it beneficial and patriotic service. Indeed, the age of those eligible for service in the Guard was lowered to accommodate those desiring membership. The first high school unit of the Tennessee State Guard formed in early 1943 at Gainesboro's Central High School.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The parade marshal for the Army Day Parade was Col. H. H. Corson of the Tennessee State Guard. He and his motorcycle escort led the army units with 900 infantrymen, bands, and artillery attachments. Various other military organizations participated in the event. The parade marched in front of Gov. Prentice Cooper and what newspapers called the "biggest Nashville crowd in years." Planes from the Vultee plant and Civil Air Patrol flew over downtown Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four sixteen-year-olds who are gaining experience for when they attain regular Army age are shown with a twenty-six-year-old machine gun trooper. This photograph was taken during the Seventh Regiment's Large-Scale Maneuvers which took place in Cookeville, Tennessee. These young men were chosen at random from a crowd of some seven hundred enlisted men assembled at the Cookeville armory.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Members of the Seventh Regiment of the Tennessee State Guard participated in the first large-scale maneuvers of the organization held in Cookeville. Most of the maneuvers took place on the farm of Captain Joe Scott. The maneuvers included simulated paratroop landings. Several planes of the Civilian Air Patrol also participated in the maneuvers. The maneuvers were declared a success and proved the State Guard could handle a major defense problem.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Construction began on the wartime training camp known as Camp Campbell on January 12, 1942. The initial determination to designate Tennessee as the official address of the camp due to its nearness to Clarksville was reversed on September 23, 1942, and Kentucky became its official state of address. Camp Campbell trained and supported numerous military units during World War II and encompassed 102,414 acres. Its status changed to permanent military installation in 1950, and its name changed to Fort Campbell.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee State Guard was formed in 1941 to serve as the state's volunteer military force after the Tennessee National Guard had been federalized for service in World War II. With the governor functioning as Commander-in-Chief, the State Guard's duties involved maintaining order, acting as an anti-sabotage unit, assisting during domestic and natural emergencies, cooperating with local and federal military authorities, and performing assigned armed forces duty in the state.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The journal indicates that the State Guard conducted drills to deal with potential riot problems. Camp Forrest operated as a major World War II training camp, hospital center, and maneuvers base from 1941 to 1946. Having been constructed east of Tullahoma and near the site of the old Camp Peay National Guard Camp, it occupied 85,000 acres, and eventually became a prisoner of war camp as well.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The brigades of the Tennessee State Guard were formed in May of 1942 as a result of a reorganization. The First Brigade was comprised of the First (Memphis) and Fifth (Jackson) Regiments. The Second Brigade was comprised of the Second (Nashville), Seventh (Cookeville), and Tenth (Pulaski) Regiments. The Third Brigade was comprised of the Third (Kingsport) and Sixth (Chattanooga) Regiments. The brigade headquarters were Memphis, Nashville, and Knoxville, respectively.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Second Infantry Brigade was formed by a May 1942 reorganization of the Tennessee State Guard. It was commanded by Brig. Gen. This map was probably produced to assist in the staging of State Guard maneuvers and exercises.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee State Guard was formed in 1941 to serve as the state's volunteer military force after the Tennessee National Guard had been federalized for service in World War II. With the governor functioning as Commander-in-Chief, the State Guard's duties involved maintaining order, acting as an anti-sabotage unit, assisting during domestic and natural emergencies, cooperating with local and federal military authorities, and performing assigned armed forces duty in the state.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Accompanying these maps is a typed note signed by Brig. Gen.
